Title: Introduction
General: Is there an introduction and does it properly motivate the paper.
Specific: Introduction can be a summary of Prevatt et al. Must cite Prevatt et al.,

Title: Research Questions
General: Are the research questions stated clearly? Do they reference the right population and variables? Are they scientific and not statistical questions?, Are the research questions stated clearly?
Specific: Do they reference the right population and variables?  Are they only the ones used in this reanalysis?

Title: Sample Description
General: Is the method or recruitment, selection, inclusion/exclusion criteria described? Is the assignment of treatment groups properly described?
Specific: Must cite Prevatt et al. Must note non-random selection. Must note different sampling procedures for ADHD and Reference groups.

Title: Measures Section
General: Is how the measure was collected and it scale properly described?
Specific: Must describe min/max values for measures. Should include Anxiety, Panic and Hyperactivity and Innattentiveness measures. Should not include measures not used in secondary analysis.

Title: Data Description
General: For discrete (nominal/ordinal) variables, are the groups clearly defined? Is the distribution of the groups in the sample defined? For continuous (interval/ratio scale) variables, are the mins and maxes given.
Specific: Percentage distributions for Gender, Year & Race. Barplot/Pie chart for Year & Race

Title: Data Cleaning
General: Have the missing value codes be properly marked? Are out-of-range values marked as missing?  Do categorical variables have non-code labels?
Specific: Out of range values marked as missing: SAT=0, Anxiety > 6, Panic >5, Innat, Hyper >27.

Title: Distribution description for all variables
General: For discrete variables, the percentages should be given. For continuous variable, the center, spread and shape should be discussed. Also, any important patterns of missingness should be discussed.
Specific: Should include Year, Gender, Anxiety/Panic, and ADHD symptom variables.

Title: Histograms or Boxplots for All Variables
General: Are histograms or boxplots provided for all of the required variables.  Note, for full credit figures should be referenced in texts.
Specific: Age, Anxiety, Panic, Innatentive, Hyperactive.

Title: Create Combined Variables
General: Are the required derieved variables properly created and their distribution described?
Specific: ADHD Total = Inatt + Hyper

Title: Anxiety (Panic) by Year Comparison
General: Differences across school years on the chosen variable clearly described (mentions differences in center scale and shape) and supported with graph.
Specific: Boxplot or Histogram using Year as grouping variable, as well as statistics per group in table or text.

Title: Anxiety (Panic) by Year Graphic
General: Graph or table comparing the distributions of anxiety/panic by Year.
Specific: Stacked histograms or multiple boxplots on same axis.

Title: Cross-Tabs
General: Give a table of the treatment variable by a covariate.
Specific: Control/ADHD versus Year.

Title: C.I. for reference group Anxiety (Panic)
General: A 95% confidence interval produced for the outcome variable (Anxiety or Panic) in the control group only.
Specific: This should be a C.I. and control group only.

Title: Reference Group Distribution Graph
General: A graph for the distribution of the outcome variable in the control group.
Specific: Boxplot or histogram for just control group.

Title: Outcome by Treatement Graph
General: A comparision graph (boxplot or histogram) for the outcome variable broken down by treatement groups.
Specific: Outcome is Anxiety or Panic (student choice).  Boxplot or histograms for control and ADHD groups on same graph. t-test for outcome variable by treatment group.

Title: t-Test
General: A t-test for the effect of the group on the outcome variable with t-statistic, d.f., p-value (or critical value) and effect size. T-tests summarized in APA style.
Specific: Outcome variable is one of the Anxiety or Panic variables (student choice). Treatment variable is ADHD/Control.

Title: Effect Sizes and Interpretatoins
General: Effect sizes reported and interpretation/conclusions consistent with the t-value and d-value. Proper interpretation for t-test.
Specific: Need to interpret what this means.

Title: Sensitivity Analysis
General: A second analysis run for t-test without graduate students to judge sensitivity to the target group. This should both be performed and discussed as a sensitivity analysis, not an independent test.
Specific: Analysis with/without graduate students should compare mean differences or effect sizes.

Title: Scatterplots
General: Are there scatterplots for relationship between the dependent variables (hyper, inatt & combined) and the independent variable (Anxiety or Panic)
Specific: Three scatterplots, with chosen response variable as Y and innat, hyper and ADHD total as X. Should include line.

Title: Linearity Check
General: For each regression, does the paper check that the relationship is linear, and not non-linear. Note that no relationship, is not the same as non-linear.
Specific: Linearity should be discussed and point to scatterplot as evidence. Any resonable conclustions is acceptable.  Including lowess curves on scatterplots is good.

Title: Equation of Line
General: Is the equation of the line presented and are X and Y identified.
Specific: Three equations, one for each X variable.

Title: Correlation
General: Is the correlation (r or R-squared) given and interpreted for each relationship.
Specific: Three Correlations or R-squared values.

Title: By Group Scatterplots
General: Are the groups identified by using colors/symbols on the scatterplot. Is whether or not the relationship is similar across groups.
Specific: This only needs to be done for one of the three X values. Using only colors is a style issue, not a correctness one. Discussion should point to figure.

Title: Regression ANOVA
General: Is the ANOVA or Regression t-test presented, and interpreted.
Specific: Should present ANOVA test for relationship or t-test for slopes in APA style. Students will not be able to do this until Unit 18.

Title: Research Paper
General: Does the paper read like a research paper? Will it be be clear to an intelligent reader with no background in the subject?

Title: APA Style
General: Does is roughly follow APA outline and style guides? Is the writing in academic style?

Title: Structure
General: Are proper section headings.  Do all paragraphs hang together.

Title: Consistent Labeling
General: Are there no ambiguous noun or pronoun references?  Are all variables (e.g., X, Y) defined.  Ar all abbreviations written out.  Are figures and tables numbered consistently.

Title: Statistical Language
General: Are statistical terms like "significance", "independence" and "correlation" used correctly.  Are the limitations of the expressions properly expressed.

Title: Concision
General: Is the language not excessively wordy, with many unnecessary transitions or multiple qualifications.

Title: All claims supported
General: All claims made in the text are justified with data or references.
Specific: Don't just tell me "this is important", tell my why it is important.

Title: Other text issues.
General: See "Feedback" tab of https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OmW9VpnRmmTf6w5-taiPltdrKv_kVhe6PPOo1BDipDI/edit?usp=sharing

Title: Figures and Tables referenced in the text
General: Figures and tables should be numbered, captioned and mentioned in the text.

Title: Presentaiton Graphics
General: Are the graphs and tables of presentation quality?
Specific: Tables should not have heavy lines between entries, preferably APA style.

Title: Axes and Table Labels.
General: Labels should be full lables, not abbreviated SPSS variable names

Title: Choice of graphs
General: Are the appropriately chosen? Are they referenced in the text?
Specific: Don't dump SPSS tables into the document without thinking

Title: Choice of statistics
General: Do they contain appropriate material, or are there extraneous data included? Can they be understood with minimal reference to the text?

Title: Digits
General: Are there appropriate numbers of digits for values in the text and the tables.
Specific: Most variables in this data set are integer valued, so

Title: Accessability
General: Will figures and tables be usable in black and white printing.
Specific: Use symbols and not just shapes for groups in scatterplots.

Title: Other graphical issues.
General: See "Feedback" tab of https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OmW9VpnRmmTf6w5-taiPltdrKv_kVhe6PPOo1BDipDI/edit?usp=sharing
